titleStmt.title: On the words──Brother protestants, and fellow Christi-
ans, so familiarly used by the advocates for the repeal

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: IN December last, a certain man of the city of Dublin openly threatened and swore, before many hundred people, that upon the first opportunity, by the help of ruffians, he would murder or maim the dean of S. Patrick's. Upon which, thirty one of the principal inhabitants of the liberty of the dean and chapter of S. Patrick's, signed a Paper, to this effect: `That out of their great love and respect to the dean, to whom the whole kingdom hath so many obligations, they would endeavour to defend the life and limbs of the said dean, against a certain man, and all his ruffians and murderers'. With which Paper, they, in the name of themselves, and all the inhabitants of the said Liberty, attended the dean on January the 8th; who being extremely ill in bed of a giddiness and deafness, and not able to receive them, immediately dictated a very grateful answer, which was published in my brother FOG's last Journal. The occasion of the certain man's declaration of his villainous design against the dean, was a frivolous unproved suspicion, that he had written some lines in verse reflecting upon him; of which the following is a genuine copy, sent from Ireland to a gentleman here.

After I had sent these verses to the press, I was informed by a book-seller, that they had been printed in a thing called a Supplement to the Gentleman's Magazine. But as that piratical compilation is read much more in the country, than in town; I imagined, that our sensible and judicious readers, who are always for going to the fountain-head, would not probably, unless by mere chance, ever see these verses in the Supplement. The barbarous threats of the certain man against the dean, and the affectionate zeal of so many persons in his defence, having made a great noise, and excited a great curiosity to know the original cause of both; to satisfy this curiosity, was the sole end of publishing the verses here, without any more approbation of them, than of the intended assassination or mutilation to which they gave occasion.
An inundation, says the fable,
O'erflow'd a farmer's barn and stable;
Whole ricks of hay and stacks of corn,
Were down the sudden current borne;
While things of heterogeneous kind,
Together float with tide and wind;
The generous wheat forgot its pride;
And sail'd with litter side by side;
Uniting all, to shew their amity,
As in a general calamity.
A ball of new-dropt horses dung,
Mingling with apples in the throng,
Say'd to the pippin, plump, and prim,
`See, brother, how we apples swim!'Thus LAMB, renown'd for cutting corns,
An offer'd fee from RADCLIFFE scorns;
`Not for the world──we doctors, brother,
`Must take no fee of one another.
Thus to a Dean some Curate sloven,
Subscribes, Dear Sir, Your brother loving.
Thus all the foot-men, shoe-boys, porters,
About S. James's, cry We courtiers.
Thus H─────-E in the house will prate,
`Sir, We the ministers of state'.
Thus at the bar that booby B──────,
Tho', half a crown out-pays his sweats worth;
Who knows in law, nor text, nor margent,
Calls SINGLETON his brother serjeant;
And thus fanatic saints, tho, neither in
Doctrine, or discipline our brethren,
Are brother Protestants and Christians,
As much as Hebrews and Philistines:
But in no other sense, than nature
Has made a rat our fellow-creature.
Lice from your body suck their food;
But is a louse your flesh and blood?
Tho' born of human filth and sweat, it
May well be say'd man did beget it.
But maggots in your nose and chin,
As well may claim you for their kin.Yet critics may object, Why not?
Since lice are brethren to a S────t;
Which made our swarm of sects determine
Employments for their brother vermine.
But be they English, Irish, Scottish,
What Protestant can be so sottish,
While o'er the Church these clouds are gathering,
To call a swarm of lice his brethren?As MOSES, by divine advice,
In Egypt turn'd the dust to lice;
And as our sects, by all descriptions,
Have hearts more harden'd than Egyptians;
As from the trodden dust they spring,
And turn'd to lice infest the king:
For pity's sake it would be just,
A rod should turn them back to dust.Let folks, in high, or holy stations,
Be proud of owning such relations;
Let courtiers hug them in their bosom,
As if they were afraid to lose 'em:
While I, with humble JOB, had rather,
Say to corruption──Thou'rt my father.
For he that has so little wit,
To nourish vermin, must be bit.811-34RB
